title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: China Evergrande Pledges to Play by the Book; Brooklyn Buildings' Lender Gets Auction Reopened
text:
China Evergrande promised to play by the book. The embattled property developer said it aims to announce a global restructuring plan within six months and it would respect offshore creditors' legal rights.

Evergrande, during its first call with offshore bondholders on Wednesday, promised to follow the rule of law and respect bondholders' claims including the company's secured offshore assets, according to people familiar with the matter. The company also said its founder and Chairman Xu Jiayin might provide additional financial support to the company to support its restructuring.

A group of Evergrande's foreign creditors last week threatened legal action that could potentially include liquidation of the company's assets. The group said it was fully within its rights to do so after a continued lack of engagement from Evergrande since the company defaulted in December. The company urged creditors for more patience on Wednesday as it hires auditors to complete due diligence on its business segments and subsidiaries.

Brooklyn properties' bankruptcy sale reopened. A bankruptcy judge, instead of approving the winning bid at a confirmation hearing, reopened the auction for nine Brooklyn real-estate properties backed by landlord Chaskiel Strulovitch. An outside bidder and the buildings' top creditor complained about a sale process riddled with confusion and persuaded the judge overseeing the bankruptcy case, who ordered a redo after concluding that auction participants might have acted differently had the correct procedures been followed.

Economy

Fed signals March rate hike. The Federal Reserve held short-term interest rates steady on Wednesday and signaled intentions to raise them in mid-March, the latest turn toward removing stimulus to temper elevated inflation. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell said the central bank's rate-setting committee was ready to raise rates at its March 15-16 meeting.

The central bank approved one final round of asset purchases, which will bring that stimulus program to a conclusion by March. Officials continued deliberations at their two-day meeting over how and when to shrink the Fed's $9 trillion securities portfolio, which has more than doubled since March 2020.

"The economy no longer needs sustained monetary policy support."

— Jerome Powell, Federal Reserve Chairman

Bankruptcy

Legal scholars accuse J&J of abusing bankruptcy code. A group of law professors criticized Johnson & Johnson's bid to use chapter 11 to settle about 38,000 personal injury cases tied to its talcum-based products, saying the company's strategy is an abuse of the bankruptcy system.

The group of seven professors on Tuesday urged Judge Michael Kaplan of the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Trenton, N.J., to dismiss a J&J's subsidiary, LTL Management, from chapter 11. The scholars said allowing the case to proceed "would add to an evolving roadmap for other companies facing liability to manufacture a sham entity to unfairly rid themselves of liability". — Jonathan Randles

Defunct Philadelphia refiner settles with insurers. Philadelphia Energy Solutions has reached a tentative settlement with insurers over property damage claims. Kenneth Frenchman, lawyer for the defunct oil refiner, on Wednesday told the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del. that the sides had settled the case "in principle" and wanted to work on documentation.

Mr. Frenchman had said in his opening argument on Monday that the company estimated the cost to replace or repair the property would be $301.7 million. The insurers projected roughly $167 million. Philadelphia Energy filed for bankruptcy in 2019 after a fire and explosion permanently crippled its refinery complex. Creditor ICBC Standard Bank PLC was also a plaintiff in the insurance lawsuit. — Becky Yerak

In Other News

The Boy Scouts of America accused sexual abuse claimant lawyer Timothy Kosnoff of misconduct, saying he was live-tweeting confidential chapter 11 information. (Law360)

Oaktree Capital Management seized a vast Hong Kong plot where the chair of ailing property manager China Evergrande Group had intended to build a Versailles-like mansion. (Financial Times)

Geo Group Inc., one of the largest operators of private detention facilities in the U.S., probably will reach a debt exchange deal with its lenders that would be tantamount to default, according to S&P Global Ratings. (Bloomberg)

Reality-television star Erika Girardi has been asked to turn over a set of $750,000 diamond earrings as a bankruptcy trustee continues to investigate her estranged husband Tom and his former law firm. (People)
